citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On January 11, 2023, the attending veterinarian mistakenly administered 12mg of Moxidectin to goat “Bert” for the
treatment of internal and external parasites. Based upon weight, Bert should have received 2.8mg of the Moxidectin. No
adverse effects of the overdose were noted after 6hrs of monitoring.
Medications for treatment of illnesses must be administered in accordance with established veterinary practices. Methods
to prevent and treat disease must be appropriate to ensure the animals received safe and effective treatment. Correct by
11/27/23

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Vanessa, an 8 year old female capybara with chronic enteritis had an endoscopy procedure performed on March 4, 2022
at another facility. During and following the procedure, it was noted that the body temperature for the capybara was low
ranging from less than 89.2F to 92.7F Appropriate measures were taken to warm the capybara prior to transport back to
the Zoo. The capybara was placed in its enclosure housing building. No additional measures or monitoring for body
temperature were performed during transport or after being placed in the housing building. The capybara was noted to be
awake but sedate when the keepers left for the evening. The capybara was found deceased on the following morning of
March 5, 2022. Monitoring and care following the endoscopic procedure was inadequate to ensure that the capybara
successfully recovered from anesthesia.
Shiloh, a 19 year old river otter, was anesthetized for an exam for weakness in the hind legs on January 26, 2022. The
otter was placed in an incubator following the exam for monitoring. The otter was checked on and vitals taken every 15-30
minutes from 9:00am -4:00pm. While “Shiloh” was in an incubator, no body temperatures were taken between 4:00pm
and 6:30pm. At the 6:30pm check, “Shiloh’s body temperature was 107.5, a significant increase from the normal
temperature reading of 102.5 at 4:00pm. Appropriate measure were taken to reduce the body temperature to normal.
However, body temperature was not monitored frequently enough to detect the increase in temperature in a timely
manner. Monitoring following the exam under was inadequate to ensure the otter's body temperature remain in a normal
range.
Post procedural care should include adequate monitoring to ensure appropriate recovery. Monitoring should include
checking the body temperature of an animal at an acceptable frequency to ensure it remains in a normal range. Policies
and procedure should be developed and followed to ensure animals receive appropriate post procedural care. Correct by
11/27/2023

On July 3, 2023, a keeper reported the paws of Andean bear "Pinocchio" were "red and seemed very sensitive". After
examination by the attending veterinarian, it was determined that Pinocchio sustained paw burns from the concrete floor
when spending time in the outdoor portion of the enclosure in during periods of direct sunlight. The bear had been
temporarily housed at the onsite veterinary clinic in an indoor/outdoor (full access) enclosure with a concrete floor since
June 2023. Animals should be handled as carefully as possible to prevent physical harm or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by 11/27/23
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
CHRISTINA RADZAI, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On January 11, 2023, the attending veterinarian mistakenly administered 12mg of Moxidectin to goat “Bert” for the 
treatment of internal and external parasites. Based upon weight, Bert should have received 2.8mg of the Moxidectin. No 
adverse effects of the overdose were noted after 6hrs of monitoring.  
 
Medications for treatment of illnesses must be administered in accordance with established veterinary practices. Methods 
to prevent and treat disease must be appropriate to ensure the animals received safe and effective treatment. Correct by 
11/27/23 
2.40(b)(5)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Vanessa, an 8 year old female capybara with chronic enteritis had an endoscopy procedure performed on March 4, 2022 
at another facility. During and following the procedure, it was noted that the body temperature for the capybara was low 
ranging from less than 89.2F to 92.7F Appropriate measures were taken to warm the capybara prior to transport back to 
the Zoo. The capybara was placed in its enclosure housing building. No additional measures or monitoring for body 
temperature were performed during transport or after being placed in the housing building. The capybara was noted to be 
awake but sedate when the keepers left for the evening. The capybara was found deceased on the following morning of 
March 5, 2022. Monitoring and care following the endoscopic procedure was inadequate to ensure that the capybara 
successfully recovered from anesthesia. 
 
Shiloh, a 19 year old river otter, was anesthetized for an exam for weakness in the hind legs on January 26, 2022. The 
otter was placed in an incubator following the exam for monitoring. The otter was checked on and vitals taken every 15-30 
minutes from 9:00am -4:00pm. While “Shiloh” was in an incubator, no body temperatures were taken between 4:00pm 
and 6:30pm. At the 6:30pm check, “Shiloh’s body temperature was 107.5, a significant increase from the normal 
temperature reading of 102.5 at 4:00pm. Appropriate measure were taken to reduce the body temperature to normal. 
However, body temperature was not monitored frequently enough to detect the increase in temperature in a timely 
manner. Monitoring following the exam under was inadequate to ensure the otter's body temperature remain in a normal 
range.

Post procedural care should include adequate monitoring to ensure appropriate recovery. Monitoring should include 
checking the body temperature of an animal at an acceptable frequency to ensure it remains in a normal range. Policies 
and procedure should be developed and followed to ensure animals receive appropriate post procedural care. Correct by 
11/27/2023 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On July 3, 2023, a keeper reported the paws of Andean bear "Pinocchio" were "red and seemed very sensitive". After 
examination by the attending veterinarian, it was determined that Pinocchio sustained paw burns from the concrete floor 
when spending time in the outdoor portion of the enclosure in during periods of direct sunlight. The bear had been 
temporarily housed at the onsite veterinary clinic in an indoor/outdoor (full access) enclosure with a concrete floor since 
June 2023. Animals should be handled as carefully as possible to prevent physical harm or unnecessary discomfort. 
Correct by 11/27/23 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CHRISTINA RADZAI, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
